prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out whether the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author's friend has been through five marriages, each with different fathers for her kids, and none of them pay child support. The friend keeps asking the author questions that are pretty much insults, comparing the author's dating life and work. The author finally responds by pointing out that the friend's situation with the five kids and no support is a reason why she's having trouble dating. The friend got angry and hung up, and now mutual friends are taking the friend's side, saying the author is being privileged and a bad friend.

First, I need to assess the context. The friend has been making personal and insulting remarks for two years. The author tried to brush them off politely, but eventually, when the friend asked again, the author gave a blunt answer. The key here is whether the truth was a valid response given the prior behavior.

The author's response was honest, pointing out a real issue that could affect dating. However, it's a sensitive topic. The friend's situation is her own life, and while the author's statement might be factually true, delivering it in that manner might have come off as harsh or judgmental, especially considering the history of insults. Even if the friend was being rude, the author's response could be seen as crossing a line by addressing personal matters. The friends' reactions suggest that they perceive the author's statement as hurtful and privileged, which might indicate that the author overstepped. The author's intention was to be truthful and stop the insults, but the method might not have been the best approach. A better approach might have been to address the friend's behavior without being critical of her personal life. So, while the friend's behavior was bad, the author's response might still be considered wrong because it was direct and possibly unkind, even if truthful.
